data.title: [Feature Request] Resolve CTRL clicks for identifiers that are defined 2+ base classes up
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 
[test.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1346856/test.zip)

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
cpptools|ms-|0.13.0

Please see the attached project.  When an inheritance identifier that doesn't exist in the parent class but is defined in the parent class' parent, ctrl clicking does not resolve all the way up until it finds an identifier.  I believe this is part of the C++ inheritance spec but you may want to double verify that.
[test.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1346857/test.zip)

data.title: Easier way to add items to "files to include" box
data.body:
From https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/17164#issuecomment-333295055

We could have a 'browse' button to add external folders to the 'files to include' search box.

Example from Sublime:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/323878/31050768-3244a0f4-a60a-11e7-9078-b220d80deb7f.png)

data.title: Both default autoformatting and user configured Clang have stopped working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
cpptools|ms-|0.13.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create new folder
2. Open folder using VSCode
3. Create new file called foo.h
4. Add the following code to the new file (with bad whitespacing and everything)

```
#pragma once

class Foo {
                  public:
bool hi = false;
};
```

5. Press the auto format hotkeys (you will have to add these to your keybindings.json; I made mine ctrl+shift+f)

Expected: Formats class
Actual: Nothing happens

Note, I have also tried this using the following settings and placing a .clang-format file into the same directory as the header file:

```
{
    "window.zoomLevel": 0,
    "workbench.sideBar.location": "left",
    "terminal.integrated.cursorBlinking": true,
    "editor.tabCompletion": true,
    "editor.formatOnType": false,
    "editor.formatOnSave": true,
    "editor.formatOnPaste": true,
    "C_Cpp.intelliSenseEngine": "Default",
    "C_Cpp.clang_format_path": "C:/Program Files/LLVM/bin/clang-format.exe",
    "C_Cpp.clang_format_style": "file",
    "workbench.colorTheme": "Visual Studio Light",
    "editor.acceptSuggestionOnEnter": "smart",
    "git.enableSmartCommit": true
}
```

Please fix this (or let me know what I'm doing wrong).  It makes checking in code and having to check the formatting of everything very painful.  This was working just before I let VSCode update yesterday.

Thanks

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Replace all doesn't work when there are > 999 matches
data.body: - VSCode Version: Version 1.16.1 (1.16.1) - OS Version: macOS High Sierra Version 10.13 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open file with lots of text. 2. Replace text that matches thousands of times 3. Observe nothing happens Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: [Feature Request] Support edit time browsing of source-maps of node_modules/ dependencies when source maps are available?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1 (1.16.1)
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

Some npm modules ship with sourcemaps (.map files or inline sourcemaps) and compiled js.  When source maps are present vscode is quite successful at presenting the sourcemapped codebase when debugging.

There are still gaps in the experience though when I want to set a breakpoint somewhere in one of my compiled node_modules/ packages.   I have to navigate to the compiled code, set a breakpoint somewhere in the compiled output, start the debugger, and then I'll end up in the original source through sourcemap translation with a  nice debugger experience ...  It would be amazing if vscode offered a mechanism that allowed directly navigating the sourcemaps of npm modules when available (in some kind of non-editable mode since changes to such a source-mapping presentation would of necessity not behave as expected without integration with the module's build process).  This way I could set breakpoints in a representation of the original source rather than it's compiled output.

This feature would also provide better readability ergonomics for browsing the code of my project's npm dependencies.  There's a large speed and convenience difference between peaking at the code on my disk in my editor vs (1) figuring out the version of the project on my disk and then (2) navigating to that version of that project's codebase wherever it happens to live (in practice this experience usually means opening the project on github and having a much worse code navigation experience than exists in vscode).

data.title: Generators in TypeScript messes up debugging
data.body:
I used generators in my typescript. after that it doesn't stops in the breakpoints I put in the ts file.
Instead I had to put the breakpoints in the js file. 

I think this is caused by the generator function generated by typescript at the top, which messes up the line number of both file.

Is there something I missing, new to this typescript thing.

data.title: No results found when searching across all file managed by OneDrive (all files on device)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 (insiders preview) 10.0.16299 Build 16299.
I don't have the current release, so can't compare.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a OneDrive folder in VSCode. Note, all files have a green check status and are 'Available on this device'
2. Ctrl+Shift+F to search across all files
3. Enter a string that should produce results and press Enter
4. No results found
5. Copy the directory outside OneDrive. Repeat steps 1-3 and results are returned

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: TypeScript: aggregate errors for file from all projects
data.body:
I have a project with three folders, two of which are TS projects and the third of which is shared between them:

- shared
- service-worker (with `tsconfig.json`)
- browser (with `tsconfig.json`)

Both "browser" and "service-worker" depend on "shared".

However, when I open a file in "shared", I only see errors related to one of the `tsconfig.json`s—usually this will be the `tsconfig.json ` used for the file I navigated from previously.

It would be great if VSCode could aggregate all errors for the current file for all matching TS projects.

data.title: CTRL+BACKSPACE in Git message editor intercepted by active file text editor
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->
When i have a file editor tab opened and I try to write a commit message for git repo, and use shortcuts that include CTRL (ctrl+backspace, ctrl+delete) - active file text editor intercepts those keyboard events and handles it modifying the file instead of modifying the message.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10/7 Pro x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a repo folder in vscode
2. Edit a file from that repo vscode text editor. hit CTRL+S to make git recognize changes. (keep editor's tab opened)
3. Switch to Source control panel in side bar. You should see the file that you modified in the list of changes to commit
4. In message editor start type "Word1 word2", then press CTRL+Backspace (to remove last word in the message)

**Expected result:**

message editor removes a word before cursor ("word2")

**Actual result:**

Active file text editor removes word before the last know position of a cursor in it

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

data.title: Weird font issue
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

One day, I hopped on Visual Studio Code and this happened:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16949253/31047363-cf59ea84-a5ce-11e7-8ad0-c16cedb524da.png)

I haven't touched any settings that have to do with the font family.

Side note: I reinstalled and same issue.

**Side note 2: I reinstalled and removed `~/Library/Application Support/Code` and it fixed the font issue.**

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

I don't know how this occured.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: LF/CRLF silent change on Git Diff View. Statusbar shows wrong info. No warning.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

Note: LF/CRLF on statusbar doesn't change on switching window in Git Diff View 

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: linux

Steps to Reproduce:

Have a file saved in repository as CRLF. Open VSCode in Linux, open Git tab, pick the file. Git will show it as having changed but when switching active tab (inner window) on Git Diff View, LF/CRLF status is not updated. And there isn't any warning on the change between LF/CRLF.

It shows the file having changed but having no visible change. There should have some warning as the content is the same and change being the difference between LF->CRLF, this is problematic.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Don't try to "open" executables when clicked in the explorer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Compile your code to some *.exe file, which shows up in the explorer
2. Left-click on it.
3. VS-Code tries to open the file, and complains it's "binary", although opening executable files makes no sense.

VS-Code might not know about all possible binary formats, but it really should at least recognize the OS's own executable files. Alternatively, it could just "run" the files; at least that would make some sense.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Compound launch config no longer works
data.body:
I don't know when this started failing as it's been a while since I last used it. I have a compound launch config to allow debugging both my extension and its debug adapter:

Extension + Dart Debug Server
https://github.com/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/blob/d5f1a21354a35f17e9b5d716fe7132cdaa2e2d48/.vscode/launch.json#L66

Today (latest stable Code) when I press F5 with this debug config selected, I get this message after 10 seconds in the extension host:

> Extension host did not start in 10 seconds, it might be stopped on the first line and needs a debugger to continue.

The debug output in the main Code instance shows:

```text
Debugging with inspector protocol because Node.js v8.6.0 was detected.
/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/MacOS/Electron --debugBrkPluginHost=26962 --debugId=e496bb00-d60a-4bd3-9c28-a4321c250679 --extensionDevelopmentPath=/Users/danny/Dev/Dart-Code 
node --inspect=14925 --debug-brk out/src/debug/dart_debug_entry.js --server=4711 
Debugger listening on ws://127.0.0.1:14925/a6b185f3-717c-4b23-a48f-b9492ae5876c
Debugger attached.
waiting for debug protocol on port 4711
```

The dev tools in the main Code instance show this:

> (ERROR): Cannot read property 'windows' of undefined: TypeError: Cannot read property 'windows' of undefined

data.title: Emmet doesn't want to beautify code
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0-ins
- OS Version: win7x64

If we have `div>p`:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/31046070-d741e838-a5fa-11e7-815d-d9ff5cdf57f9.png)

if will expand into:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/31046079-fab4dbd6-a5fa-11e7-8615-442382c8a1a4.png)

But if we do have something like `form>select`:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/31046098-41c63ef2-a5fb-11e7-8ffe-1042033f49a3.png)

it would be a little mess with no work of beautifier and indents: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/31046100-514bab14-a5fb-11e7-87fe-5319fe28cdb7.png)

It starts to beautify the code only if there 3+ options (inputs, etc.) in the form:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/31046115-9b9419b8-a5fb-11e7-8c68-a734ef2502f2.png)

I think it should do also for 1 and 2.
